Laboratory for Materials and Structures Institute of Innovative Research Tokyo Institute of Technology Nagatsuta-cho 4259 Midori-ku Yokohama 226-8503 Japan Graphical abstract Benzylic CH fluorination is the straightforward method for the synthesis of fluoromethylarenes, which are utilized as oxygen mimics in molecules such as nucleotides, phosphate esters and sulfate esters. We reveal that silver particles supported on a metal oxide act as an efficient catalyst for the benzylic CH fluorination of 4-methylbiphenyl with 1-fluoro-4-methyl-1,3-diazoniabicyclo[2.2.2]octane bis(tetrafluoroborate) (Selectfluor II) as a fluorinating reagent to give 4-(fluoromethyl)-1,1′-biphenyl, whereas silver oxides resulted in aromatic fluorination. Among the catalysts tested, Ag/SiO2 exhibited the highest activity for fluorination to give the fluorinated product in 75% yield. This system was applicable to larger-scale fluorination. Mechanistic studies revealed that the present fluorination likely involves single electron transfer (SET) processes between Ag particles and 4-methylbiphenyl to afford radical species. Keywords Fluorination Silver Fluoromethylarenes 1 Introduction Fluorinated compounds are widely encountered in medicinal chemistry and materials chemistry; approximately 20% of commercial pharmaceuticals and 30% of agrochemicals contain fluorine [1,2], despite of the scarcity of natural products containing fluorine atoms [3,4]. The introduction of fluorine atoms to organic compounds can impart unique physical and chemical properties, such as lipophilicity and metabolic stability to pharmaceuticals, as well as heat resistance, chemical resistance and a low friction factor to polymers, due to their small size and high electronegativity of these atoms. Among the fluorinated compounds, monofluoromethyl groups on aromatics have been utilized as oxygen mimics in molecules such as nucleotides, phosphate esters and sulfate esters [5,6]. Thus, many catalytic systems have been developed to introduce a fluorine atom at the benzylic position. Fluorination at the benzylic position has been typically performed by halogen exchange of benzyl halides [7], deoxyfluorination using N,N-diethylaminosulfur trifluoride (DAST) [8–11] and electrochemical methods [12,13]. In addition, fluoromethylarenes have been synthesized by Suzuki-Miyaura coupling with fluoromethyl halides [14,15], sequential methods assisted by removable activating groups [16–20] and reductive cross-coupling of aryl halides with fluoromethyl halides [21]. In recent years, considerable efforts have been directed toward the development of fluorination of the CH bond at the benzylic position with respect to the late-stage introduction of fluorine atoms in medicine and agrochemistry [22], and atom efficiency. In 2012, Sanford and coworkers reported Pd-catalyzed direct benzylic fluorination that required a quinolinyl group as a directing group [23,24]. It is noteworthy that manganese complexes were demonstrated to catalyze benzylic CH fluorination of secondary alkyl groups [25–28]. After these reports, several research groups have developed catalytic systems based on silver [29,30], iron [31,32] and organocatalysts [33–36] using 1-chloromethyl-4-fluoro-1,3-diazoniabicyclo[2.2.2]octane bis(tetrafluoroborate) (Selectfluor) as an electrophilic fluorinating reagent for the benzylic CH fluorination of methylarenes (Scheme 1 ); however, silver systems and organocatalysts require additives or photoirradiation, and iron catalysts have afforded only moderate yields for methylarenes. Therefore, there is a substantial requirement for a simple and efficient catalytic system for the fluorination of methylarenes. Silver nanoparticles supported on metal oxides can promote single electron transfer (SET) processes with organic compounds to form radical species [37,38]; therefore, we envisioned that a supported silver catalyst could activate methylarenes through a SET process to enable benzylic CH fluorination via radical mechanism. Herein, we report on benzylic CH fluorination of 4-methylbiphenyl over a supported silver catalyst to produce the corresponding fluoromethylarene. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Supports were pretreated at 500 °C for 2 h in air before use. SiO2 (Q10) was provided by Fuji Silysia Chemical. ZrO2 (JRC-ZRO-6) and Al2O3 (JRC-ALO-9) were obtained from the Catalysis Society of Japan as reference catalysts. TiO2 (ST-01), Nb2O5·nH2O and MgO were supplied from Ishihara Sangyo Kaisha, Companhia Brasileira de Metalurgia e Mineraçáo and Ube Material Industries, respectively. Silver nitrate, 1-chloromethyl-4-fluoro-1,3-diazoniabicyclo[2.2.2]octane bis(tetrafluoroborate) (Selectfluor), N-fluorobenzenesulfonimide (NFSI), 1-fluoropyridinium triflate, 1,4-dioxane, benzotrifluoride, and 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl (TEMPO) were purchased from TCI Chemical and used as-received. 1-Fluoro-4-methyl-1,3-diazoniabicyclo[2.2.2]octane bis(tetrafluoroborate) (Selectfluor II) was purchased from Manchester Organics. 2,6-Di-t-butylphenol, CDCl3, CD3CN and tetrahydrofuran (THF)-d 8 were purchased from Kanto Chemical. AgO and Ag2O were purchased from Aldrich. 2.2 Instruments Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at −196 °C with a surface area analyzer (Quantachrome Nova-4200e). Prior to the adsorption measurements, the samples were degassed in situ under vacuum at 150 °C for 1 h. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface areas were estimated over the relative pressure (P/P 0) range from 0.05 to 0.3. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns for all samples were recorded on a diffractometer (Ultima IV, Rigaku; Cu Kα, λ = 40 kV–40 mA) equipped with a high-speed one-dimensional detector (DteX Ultra, Rigaku). Diffraction data were collected in the range of 2θ = 10–80° at 0.02° steps with a scan rate of 20° min–1. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) measurements were conducted using a field emission transmission electron microscope (JEM-2100F, JEOL) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV (the samples were dispersed on a carbon sheet with ethanol, and dried). Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) spectra were recorded using a spectrometer (Biospin Avance III, Bruker, 1H, 400 MHz; 19F, 376 MHz) with 5 mm sample tubes. 1H NMR chemical shifts (δ) are reported in parts per million (ppm) downfield from SiMe4. 19F NMR chemical shifts (δ) are reported in parts per million downfield from CF3Cl and are referenced to α,α,α-trifluorotoluene (δ = –63.9) as an internal standard. Benzylic fluorination was performed with an organic synthesizer (ALHB-80 & DTC-200HZ-3000, Techno Applications). Flash column chromatography was conducted using an automated flash chromatography system (Smart Flash EPCLC AI-580s, Yamazen). Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) spectra were recorded on a spectrometer (NEX DE, Rigaku). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; ESCA-3200 Shimadzu) measurements were performed using Mg Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). Samples were fixed on double-sided carbon tape. The binding energies were calibrated using C (1s peak at 384.6 eV). 2.3 Catalyst preparation Supported silver catalysts were prepared using the impregnation method [39]. Typically, AgNO3 (85 mg) and the support (450 mg) were dissolved in H2O (20 mL). The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight and then evaporated. The obtained solid was dried at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined at 500 °C (5 °C/min) for 4 h to yield the 10 wt% Ag/support. 2.4 Procedure for catalytic benzylic fluorination The catalytic reaction was conducted in a 30 mL glass vessel containing a magnetic stirring bar. A typical procedure for catalytic benzylic fluorination was as follows: silver catalyst (50 mg), 4-methylbiphenyl (0.5 mmol), Selectfluor II (1 mmol), 1,4-dioxane (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL) were charged into the reaction vessel. The reaction solution was heated at 50 °C for 2 h. After cooling to room temperature, a portion of the reaction mixture was diluted with CD3CN and then analyzed using 19F NMR with α,α,α-trifluorotoluene as an internal standard. 2.5 Procedure for larger-scale fluorination of 4-methylbiphenyl The larger-scale fluorination of 4-methylbiphenyl was conducted in a 200 mL round-bottom flask containing a magnetic stirring bar. 4-methylbiphenyl (10 mmol), Ag/SiO2 (2 g), Selectfluor II (20 mmol), 1,4-dioxane (40 mL) and H2O (40 mL) were charged into the flask. The reaction mixture was heated at 50 °C for 2 h. After the reaction was completed, the catalyst was separated by filtration. The filtrate was extracted with EtOAc (20 mL × 3). The combined organic phase was washed with brine (50 mL) and then evaporated. The crude product was purified by column chromatography (silica gel packed column with hexane as eluent) to give 4-(fluoromethyl)-1,1′-biphenyl [40] in 70% yield (1.30 g). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.62–7.56 (m, 4H), 7.50–7.31 (m, 5H), 5.41 (d, J = 47.9 Hz, 2H). 19F NMR (376 MHz, CDCl3): δ –206.1 (t, J = 47.9 Hz). 2.6 Procedure for conversion of p-hydroquinone to p-benzoquinone In a glove box under an argon atmosphere, Ag/SiO2 (20 mg, pre-reduced at 200 °C with H2), p-hydroquinone (0.02 mmol) and THF-d 8 (0.5 mL) were added to a J-Young-capped NMR tube. The NMR tube was heated in an incubator (30 °C) for 20 h. The yield of p-benzoquinone was determined by 1H NMR measurement based on phenanthrene as an internal standard. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Prepared silver catalysts were characterized with XRD and TEM. Fig. 1 shows XRD patterns for the supported silver catalysts. The diffraction peaks at 38.2°, 44.4°, 64.6° and 77.5° can be assigned to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes of a face center cubic (fcc) lattice of metallic silver (JCPDS 00-001-1167), respectively. Impurity phases of other silver oxide species were not observed, except for Nb2O5. When Nb2O5 was used as a support, silver niobate (Ag2Nb5O11) was generated instead of metallic silver (Fig. 1b). Table 1 summarizes the morphological characteristics, including the specific surface area, particle size, and crystallite diameter. From TEM images of Ag/SiO2 (Fig. 2 a), the mean diameter was estimated to 4.9 ± 3.7 nm and the range of particle size was determined to be from 2 nm to 32 nm, which is a relatively broad size distribution. The diameter of large particles observed in the TEM image is close to the crystallite diameter (29 nm) calculated from XRD measurements. The mean diameters of silver particles supported on other oxides were also determined to be 5.8 ± 6.9 (TiO2), 15.7 ± 6.4 (Al2O3), 16.1 ± 6.2 (ZrO2), and 71.6 ± 30.7 nm (MgO), based on the TEM observations (Fig. 3 ). These values are detached from the crystallite diameters, which suggests that some large particles are formed on the surface of the support. In the case of MgO, some silver particles seem to not be deposited on MgO. 3.2 Benzylic CH fluorination over Ag catalysts The catalytic activity of the supported silver catalyst was evaluated for the benzylic CH fluorination of 4-methylbiphenyl with 2 equivalents of Selectfluor as a fluorinating reagent in 1,4-dioxane/H2O at 50 °C for 2 h. Ag/SiO2 exhibited catalytic activity for benzylic CH fluorination to give the monofluorinated product 1 in 41% yield along with the formation of aldehyde 2 in 2% yield (Table 1, entry 1). Examinations without 1,4-dioxane or water resulted in the formation of no desired products, which indicated that mixing the solvents is necessary for the present benzylic CH fluorination, probably due to dissolution of both substrate and the fluorinating reagent. Other solvents such as EtOH, CH3CN, 1,2-dichloroethane, toluene and dimethyl formamide (DMF) were not effective for benzylic fluorination, even when combined with water. Table 2 shows the catalytic activities of the silver based catalysts, including metal oxide-supported Ag catalysts, Ag2O, AgO and AgNO3. Although the effect of the support on the silver catalysts was examined, silver catalysts with other supports exhibited lower catalytic activity than Ag/SiO2 (entries 2–5). These results suggest that the catalytic activity of the Ag catalyst was not affected by acid and base sites on the supports. Since mixture of metallic Ag and oxide species is generated on metal oxide supports by preparing with similar method [41,42], oxidation state of Ag can be differentiated by oxide supports and could have some effects on catalytic performance. Aromatic CH fluorination proceeded by the use of silver oxides and silver nitrate to afford a complex mixture of monofluoro- and difluoroaromatic compounds (entries 6–8), and these product distributions were comparable to that without a catalyst (entry 9). The screening of fluorinating reagents was then conducted using a series of electrophilic fluorinating reagents (Table 3 ). When using Selectfluor II as a fluorinating reagent, the yield of fluorinated product 1 was improved to 56% (entry 2). On the other hand, no desired product was detected by the reaction with NFSI and 1-fluoropyridinium triflate (entries 4 and 5). Further optimization studies on the reaction temperature and amount of catalyst revealed that the use of 100 mg of Ag/SiO2 increased the yield of 1 to 75% (entry 3). Fig. 4 shows time courses for conversion and each product with the silver-catalyzed benzylic fluorination of 4-methylbiphenyl under the optimized conditions. The yield of 1 reached its maximum (78%) at 2.5 h and gradually decreased over time. The product formed from mono-fluorinated product 1 could not be identified by NMR or gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) analyses, although the aromatic fluorination of 1 proceeded slightly with the remaining Selectfluor to afford difluorinated compounds containing benzylic and aromatic CF bonds. On the other hand, aldehyde 2 was formed in low yield in the early stage, and the yield of 2 was not increased with reaction progress. The initial formation of 2 could be due to the adsorbed atomic oxygen generated through the dissociation of molecular oxygen on the surface of metallic Ag [43]. A protocol using Ag/SiO2 allowed the successful implementation of this benzylic fluorination on a larger scale, highlighting the practical utility of the silver-catalyzed system (Scheme 2 ). With the optimized conditions, we carried out substrate scope of the present catalytic system; however, the benzylic fluorination did not proceed for methylarene derivatives bearing several functional groups including esters, ethers, halogens and heteroaromatics. The recovered Ag catalyst did not exhibit activity for benzylic fluorination (Scheme 3 ). The XRD peak intensity for metallic Ag for the recovered Ag catalyst decreased with respect to that for the fresh catalyst (Fig. 5 ) and the Ag loading was reduced from 9.5 to 2.4 wt% according to EDX analyses; the low reusability is thus due to the leaching of silver species. The XPS spectra of the freshly prepared Ag/SiO2 and used one for benzylic fluorination are presented in Fig. 6 . Ag 3d5/2 XPS peak is found at 368.9 eV. This value is higher than that of metallic Ag (368.2 eV) [44,45]. The present higher value of the silver binding energy is attributed to the quantum size effect of the silver clusters [46,47]. Similar shift is observed for lower-size gold clusters on amorphous carbon [48]. The leaching of silver species is also confirmed by the decrease of the XPS peak intensity by the fluorination. The Ag surface concentration is decreased from 8.2 wt% to 3.6 wt% based on Si 1 s peak. To verify whether the observed catalysis is derived from supported silver catalyst or leached silver species, the fluorination of 4-methylbiphenyl was conducted under the conditions described in entry 3 of Table 3, and Ag/SiO2 was removed from the reaction mixture by hot filtration at 1 h. The filtrate was then heated again at 50 °C. In this case, no further production of fluorinated product 1 was observed. Thus, the fluorination could proceed on the surface of the silver catalyst. However, the yield of 1 was gradually decreased probably due to the leached silver species (Fig. 7 ). 3.3 Mechanistic studies To gain insights into the mechanism of benzylic CH fluorination over supported silver catalysts, radical inhibition experiments were performed in the presence of 1 equivalent of TEMPO or dibutylhydroxytoluene (BHT) as a radical scavenger. The addition of TEMPO and BHT completely diminished the benzylic fluorination of 4-methylbiphenyl (Scheme 4 ). These results suggest that benzylic fluorination proceeded via a radical mechanism. The oxidative properties of the Ag catalyst were also confirmed by the conversion of p-hydroquinone to p-benzoquinone over Ag/SiO2 in the absence of an external oxidant (Eq. (1)). To exclude the effect of oxygen adsorption on the supported silver catalyst, freshly prepared Ag/SiO2 was pre-reduced with H2 at 200 °C for 2 h and directly transferred into the glove box without exposure to air. p-Benzoquinone was obtained in 17% yield with the pre-reduced Ag/SiO2 after stirring at 30 °C for 20 h under an Ar atmosphere. No conversion of p-hydroquinone was observed without the Ag catalyst under the same reaction conditions (Eq. (2)); therefore, the Ag particles on SiO2 have the ability to oxidize organic compounds without any activation. Such an electron-transfer process between Ag nanoparticles and organic compounds was reported based on electron paramagnetic resonance measurements using 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide as a spin trap [37]. Although the activation of silver species by electrophilic fluorinating reagents to form high valence silver species cannot be completely ruled out [49,50], we propose the working mechanism shown in Scheme 5 . Deprotonation and SET from the adsorbed methylarenes to the Ag particles generate the corresponding benzyl radical intermediate, which abstracts electrophilic fluorine in Selectfluor II to yield the monofluorinated product 1 along with an N-centered radical cation. Ammonium salt is subsequently formed through back electron transfer to the N-centered radical cation and protonation. A final desorption step turns over the catalytic cycle and releases ammonium salt into solution. The present benzylic fluorination presumably proceeded on the surface of the silver catalyst because of the inactiveness of simple silver salts for benzylic fluorination (Table 2, entries 6–8), although leaching of silver was observed in the reuse experiments (Scheme 3). Concerning about the significant solvent effects, there is the possibility of the incorporation of 1,4-dioxane into the radical pathway. 1,4-Dioxane was converted under the fluorination conditions to 1,4-dioxan-2-ol, which can be generated through the activation of CH bond of 1,4-dioxane and subsequent hydroxylation. 4 Conclusions Benzylic CH fluorination over a supported silver catalyst to afford fluoromethylarenes in good yields was demonstrated under mild reaction conditions. Metallic silver is crucial for the selective formation of fluoromethylarenes by benzylic CH fluorination instead of aromatic CH fluorination. The present system has potential for application to the larger-scale fluorination of 4-methylbiphenyl. Based on radical inhibition experiments and the oxidation of p-hydroquinone over the supported Ag catalyst, the present fluorination proceeds through a radical mechanism that includes SET processes between Ag particles and 4-methylbiphenyl. Further application and investigation of supported silver catalysts is ongoing in our laboratory. coredata.dc:description: Benzylic CH fluorination is the straightforward method for the synthesis of fluoromethylarenes, which are utilized as oxygen mimics in molecules such as nucleotides, phosphate esters and sulfate esters. We reveal that silver particles supported on a metal oxide act as an efficient catalyst for the benzylic CH fluorination of 4-methylbiphenyl with 1-fluoro-4-methyl-1,3-diazoniabicyclo[2.2.2]octane bis(tetrafluoroborate) (Selectfluor II) as a fluorinating reagent to give 4-(fluoromethyl)-1,1′-biphenyl, whereas silver oxides resulted in aromatic fluorination. Among the catalysts tested, Ag/SiO2 exhibited the highest activity for fluorination to give the fluorinated product in 75% yield. This system was applicable to larger-scale fluorination. Mechanistic studies revealed that the present fluorination likely involves single electron transfer (SET) processes between Ag particles and 4-methylbiphenyl to afford radical species.
coredata.dc:title: Benzylic CH fluorination over supported silver catalyst
